title: GitHub is Sued, and We May Learn Something About Creative Commons Licensing

last_post.content:
"I have long wondered about the interplay between the attribution requirement (in CC BY) and TDM...Does [it] need to include attribution, even if hundreds of thousands of CC BY works were mined?"
https://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2023/01/05/github-is-sued-and-we-may-learn-something-about-creative-commons-licensing/

I too have wondered about this given only vague assurances from CC BY advocates rather than anything concrete in the license itself.

BUT a much better argument is that TDM is allowed under copyright, which means this is allowable whatever the license https://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/53/2/articles/files/53-2_Carroll.pdf

title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

For the first time, just over 15% of consumers who financed a new car in the fourth quarter of 2022 committed to a monthly payment of $1,000 or more — the highest level on record — compared with 10.5% one year ago, Edmunds found.

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

An idea, I never considered. EVs need different tires than ICE cars because

3. EVs accelerate faster requiring more traction.

2) It likely will be in the list of peer servers, but I don't know that masto uses this in any meaningful way, another thing i should check out

3) yes, unfortunately, this is something that would require the instance admin to apply

4) I tried to write something like this just using clientside javascript for eg. a bookmarklet, but the CORS rules prevented me from making the fetch to the OP server. I believe a browser extension would be able to overcome that problem, and it also looks like the search API doesn't require login (which seems bad actually) and so it might not even need to have you approve it with eg. OAuth or something like that. I have only written one extremely simple browser extension before, but this is ultimately extremely simple, basically this (and then refresh the page):

fetch(<other_instance>/api/<context_endpoint>
).then( (response) => {
response.json().descendants
.forEach( (status) => {
fetch(<search_api>/<status.url>);
}
});

title: Shaking the foundations: delusions in sequence models for interaction and control

last_post.content:
If you are learning from a sequence of observations and actions, and using a probabilistic model, you should be treating the agent's actions as #causal interventions. The authors attribute the lack of causal interventions as the reason for #delusions, and also propose a way to do #MetaLearning. #MachineLearning #Causality #ReinforcementLearning

https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.10819

title: Cops Hacked Thousands of Phones. Was It Legal?

last_post.content:
In June 2020, police announced they'd hacked the EncroChat encrypted phone network. Thousands of serious criminals are now behind bars because of it.

But across Europe, legal challenges against the hacking—one of the biggest police-led hacks ever—are reaching the continent's top courts. Lawyers claim evidence has been obscured and data sharing between nations wasn't legal. There are bigger implications for encryption in general though

My latest story:

https://www.wired.com/story/encrochat-phone-police-hacking-encryption-drugs/

#hacking #encryption #data #Encrochat #news #WIRED

The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).
